entry.title: COVID: The positive side of the pandemic | COVID-19 Special

media:group.media:title: COVID: The positive side of the pandemic | COVID-19 Special
media:group.media:description:
In Madrid, a group of neighbors have come together to help vulnerable people through the pandemic and beyond. And in good news for business, the new buzz word is "nearshoring" — production is on its way back home.

entry.title: Ethiopia-Tigray peace deal: How to find common ground after bloody war | DW News

media:group.media:title: Ethiopia-Tigray peace deal: How to find common ground after bloody war | DW News
media:group.media:description:
After two years of fighting in Ethiopia, warring parties have agreed to lay down their arms, thanks to a peace deal brokered by the African Union. The conflict in the northern Tigray region has left thousands dead, millions displaced and brought famine to the region. Ethiopia's government and Tigrayan authorities agree to an "orderly, smooth and coordinated disarmament." "Restoration of law and order," "restoration of services" and, more importantly, for the people there in the region to get "unhindered access to humanitarian supplies." Now many wonder if the peace deal will hold.
Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/user/deutschewelleenglish?sub_confirmation=1

entry.title: What role will minority voters play in the US midterm elections? | DW News

media:group.media:title: What role will minority voters play in the US midterm elections? | DW News
media:group.media:description:
The economy is top of mind for minorities, especially Nevada's Latinos. In Las Vegas, many of them work in low-wage jobs in hotels and restaurants. Inflation and high rents are major concerns. What role will minority voters play in the midterm elections and — and what role will unions play?

entry.title: What signs of Russian withdrawal in Kherson could mean | DW News

media:group.media:title: What signs of Russian withdrawal in Kherson could mean | DW News
media:group.media:description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin has urged civilians to leave the city of Kherson as Ukrainian troops advance in the area.The statement is the latest signal that Russia's military may be planning to withdraw from the occupied Ukrainian city. But Ukraine says Russia could be feigning a withdrawal in order to ambush Ukrainian troops when they move into the city. As the only major city Russia has managed to capture since it invaded Ukraine, Putin will be unlikely to give Kherson up without a fight.
Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/user/deutschewelleenglish?sub_confirmation=1

entry.title: Warnings of political violence ahead of US midterms | DW News

media:group.media:title: Warnings of political violence ahead of US midterms | DW News
media:group.media:description:
US President Joe Biden called on Americans to unite against "political violence and voter intimidation" in his midterm speech on Wednesday.
His remarks about defending electoral integrity come a week out from midterm elections.
Biden's speech comes a week after an intruder broke into the home of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi in an apparent attempt to hold her hostage. Upon realizing the senior Democrat herself was out of town, the intruder attacked her husband, Paul.
Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/user/deutschewelleenglish?sub_confirmation=1

entry.title: Should Europe stop trading with China? | DW Business Special

media:group.media:title: Should Europe stop trading with China? | DW Business Special
media:group.media:description:
The EU has had its fingers burnt by Russia. A collapse in relations left it having to urgently untangle its trading relationship with Moscow. Now European leaders are wondering if they will need to do the same with China. Countries like Germany are at odds with Beijing on many ideological issues that could pose a future diplomatic threat. So is it best to begin unpicking their intertwined import and export markets now? We discuss that question and more with China watcher Clifford Coonan.
Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/user/deutschewelleenglish?sub_confirmation=1

entry.title: Energy security in an insecure world | Business Beyond

media:group.media:title: Energy security in an insecure world | Business Beyond
media:group.media:description:
Throughout modern history, global economic growth has been based on countries and industries having access to reliable, relatively cheap energy. But energy security can easily be threatened. In 2022, a slew of crises have converged to raise serious questions about this most critical of topics. The aftermath of the pandemic, raging global conflict, geopolitical rivalries and the worsening climate crisis have raised a decisive question for the planet: can it continue to power itself without deepening inequality?
Chapters:
00:00 INTRODUCTION
02:11 2022: BREAKING POINT?
05:15 WHAT IS ENERGY SECURITY?
08:10 RENEWABLE V FOSSIL FUELS
12:48 ENERGY FOR THE RICH: LNG
15:34 BATTLE OF THE SUPERPOWERS
19:24 A GREEN FUTURE. BUT WILL IT BE SECURE - AND WILL IT BE FAIR?
22:01 CREDITS
Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/user/deutschewelleenglish?sub_confirmation=1

entry.title: Twitter employees sue over Elon Musk's mass layoffs | DW News

media:group.media:title: Twitter employees sue over Elon Musk's mass layoffs | DW News
media:group.media:description:
Twitter employees are suing the company in a class action lawsuit over mass layoffs expected to be carried out on Friday. The company, recently acquired by the world's richest man Elon Musk, told employees they would be notified about terminations via email. Twitter offices are closed for the day and badge access removed. While there has been no official announcement specifying the number of layoffs, US media reports say half of Twitter's 7,500 workforce could be let go. entry.title: German Chancellor Scholz draws fire over trade trip to China | DW News

media:group.media:title: German Chancellor Scholz draws fire over trade trip to China | DW News
media:group.media:description:
Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz pressed China on its support for Russia in Ukraine during talks in Beijing on Friday with Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang. Scholz also addressed controversy over economic and human rights issues. He is traveling with a business delegation and has faced calls to reduce Germany's over-dependence on its biggest trading partner. Allies like France and the US are critical of the visit. Scholz noted that he and Chinese leader Xi Jinping are coming together at a time of "great tension." He pressed China to exert its influence on Russia in the name of peace. But while Scholz was outspoken on Russia, Li Keqiang didn't even mention China's ally by name. Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/user/deutschewelleenglish?sub_confirmation=1

entry.title: Russian troops signal withdrawal from Kherson as Ukraine moves in | DW News

media:group.media:title: Russian troops signal withdrawal from Kherson as Ukraine moves in | DW News
media:group.media:description:
Ukraine's President Volodymir Zelenskyy says Russian strikes have left some 4.5 million people without power across the country. Zelenskyy accuses Moscow of "energy terrorism" for escalating attacks on Ukraine's power grid as winter looms. Similar attacks on infrastructure have also damaged Ukraine's water supplies. Officials have asked refugees not to return to the country this winter because of fears of further shortages. And Moscow has claimed Kyiv was developing a so-called "dirty bomb," but the International Atomic Energy Agency has not found no evidence that the claim is true. Meanwhile, there are signs the Russians are withdrawing from parts of Kherson, as Ukraine appears poised to retake the strategic city. Russia has begun the mass relocation of people there, and there are troubling reports that children are being moved out of orphanages and offered up for adoption in Russia, which would constitute a war crime.
Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/user/deutschewelleenglish?sub_confirmation=1

entry.title: Live: Olaf Scholz and Li Keqiang hold press conference in China | DW News

media:group.media:title: Live: Olaf Scholz and Li Keqiang hold press conference in China | DW News
media:group.media:description:
Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz is in China for talks with Chinese officials. Overshadowing Scholz's visit is criticism of China's tacit support for Russia's invasion of Ukraine and controversy over economic and human rights issues. Scholz, who is travelling with several top business leaders, faces calls to reduce Germany's over-dependence on its biggest trading partner. Allies like France and the US are critical of the visit. And even his own coalition partners are warning against becoming too close to authoritarian regimes.

entry.title: NATO chief Stoltenberg urges Turkey to endorse Finland, Sweden accession | DW News

media:group.media:title: NATO chief Stoltenberg urges Turkey to endorse Finland, Sweden accession | DW News
media:group.media:description:
NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said on Thursday that Sweden and Finland were ready to join the military alliance.
Stoltenberg said the two Nordic states had delivered on Turkey's demands, paving the way for accession.
"It's time to welcome Finland and Sweden as members of NATO," he told a press conference alongside Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu in Istanbul.

entry.title: Protests in Iran continue despite police violence | DW News

media:group.media:title: Protests in Iran continue despite police violence | DW News
media:group.media:description:
Anti-regime demonstrations have continued in several Iranian cities despite brutal clampdowns by security forces. The fundamentalist Islamic government is calling on people to stay out of the streets, but so far, the calls have had little effect.

media:group.media:title: Preparing Ukraine for winter: Interview with EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell | DW News
media:group.media:description:
EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell accused the Russian army of wanting to put "the Ukrainians into the darkness." During a meeting in the German city of Münster, G7 foreign ministers vowed to help Ukraine through the coming winter.

entry.title: Why Germany can't make up its mind about China | DW News

media:group.media:title: Why Germany can't make up its mind about China | DW News
media:group.media:description:
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz is set to be the first G7 leader to visit China since the start of the pandemic. Despite growing concerns over Germany's dependence on China, Scholz decided to take a business delegation with him. Why can't Germany make up its mind about China?
